content: The Act titled "Cameron Gulbransen Kids Transportation Safety Act of 2007" or "K.T. Safety Act of 2007" mandates the consideration of safety standards for power windows in motor vehicles to prevent accidents involving children and others. The Secretary of Transportation must initiate a rulemaking process within 18 months to require power windows to automatically reverse direction when detecting an obstruction. If deemed reasonable and practicable, the Secretary will prescribe these safety standards under title 49. The Secretary must prescribe safety standards for power windows in vehicles under title 49 within 30 months of the Act's enactment. If no additional safety standards are deemed reasonable, a report must be submitted to relevant committees, and information on vehicle safety must be made public. Violations will be treated as a violation of a motor vehicle safety standard and noncompliant vehicles must be reported to the Secretary. The Secretary must publish noncompliant motor vehicle makes and models within 30 days of receiving the information. Any vehicle not listed is presumed to comply with safety standards. The definition of a motor vehicle excludes motorcycles and trailers. The Secretary will establish a database of injuries and deaths in nontraffic, noncrash events involving motor vehicles within 12 months of the Act's enactment. The database will include information on the number, types, and causes of injuries and deaths, as well as details on the make, model, and model year of the vehicles involved. The Secretary will establish a database of injuries and deaths in nontraffic, noncrash events involving motor vehicles. Information will be made available to the public through the Internet. Additionally, within 9 months of the Act's enactment, child safety information programs will be provided by supplementing existing programs or creating new ones, utilizing collected information. The Secretary will utilize collected information to establish priorities for the program, address risks to small children, and make program information available to the public. If deadlines cannot be met, new deadlines will be established and relevant committees will be notified. The Secretary will notify relevant committees of new deadlines if the deadlines specified under this Act cannot be met.
